title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: are the ruins of Rosyth Castle, once the seat of the Stuarts of Eosyth, a branch of the Royal House of Scotland, from -whom it is said the mother of Oliver Cromwell was descended.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The bay between the Cruicks and Rosyth Castle is called St. Margaret' s Hope, from the circumstance of the Princess Margaret, sister of Edgar Atheling, afterwards consort of Malcolm Canmore,  having been wrecked there in her flight from England, immediately after the Norman conquest.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Rosyth Castle, a large square tower, is situated in the immediate neighbourhood, close by the sea.

title: Reminiscences of childhood at Inverkeithing;
author: Simson, James
snippet: Although the weather  was wt?t, I got a good view of what was to be seen on our side of St. Margaret's Hope, including the guard-ship, the ruins of Rosyth Castle and St. Margaret's, and after these, of the Ferry and Caroline's Nose, and enjoyed the novelty of seeing familiar places from a point outside of them.

title: Reminiscences of childhood at Inverkeithing;
author: Simson, James
snippet: We passed through the arch at the Abbey on our way to " Inglis'," a famous dealer in all kinds of " soft goods," whose shop, on a pretty-wide street, looked towards the Forth, perhaps on a line leading to St. Margaret's Bay or Rosyth Castle.

title: Reminiscences of childhood at Inverkeithing;
author: Simson, James
snippet: My acquaintance with the " wide world" at this time extended no further than strolling over the Cruicks'  Peninsula, and going to and returning from school, with the following  cxcej)tions, not including three trips to Rosyth Castle, and visiting  Limekilns, as mentioned.

title: Reminiscences of childhood at Inverkeithing;
author: Simson, James
snippet: From the part of the Ferry Hills alluded to, and looking towards the west, on the same side of the firth, the ruins of Rosyth Castle present a striking object for contemplation.
